Description: Limestone stela of Pyiay: a small, round-topped stela bearing incised texts and figures in sunk relief. Pyiay stands in the centre right of the stela holding a brazier in one hand and pouring a libation from the other over an altar piled with offerings. His wife Hathor stands behind him holding more offerings. They are identified by three columns of text above the figures. On the other side of the altar is the standard of Wepwawet behind which are five wolves, one above the other. The stela has some gouges and scratches on the surface and some unevenness about the edges. There are traces of a black substance adhering to the surface in places.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Egypt, Asyut(?) (Based on stylistic similarities with other stelae from Asyut)
Curator's comments: Bibliography: Hall, 'British Museum Quarterly' 5 (London,1930-1), 18, pl. IXc; P. Munro, 'Zeitschrift für Ägyptische Sprache und Altertumskunde' 88 (Leipzig and Berlin, 1962), 52, pl. V. Durisch, BIFAO 93 (1993), 215; Kahl, Ancient Asyut (2007), 37 fig. 17
Bibliographic references: Bierbrier 1993 / Hieroglyphic texts from Egyptian stelae, etc., in the British Museum, Part 12. (Pl.82-83)
Condition: The stela is well preserved apart from some gouges and scratches on the surface and some unevenness about the edges. There are traces of a black substance adhering to the surface in places.
